results.content:
This is a great course for teaching the basics of OOP in a PHP context to beginner with a little PHP knowledge. Rob's delivery is clear and concise, with regular mini challenges to get you up and running.

The course is very much a beginner's guide as it doesn't cover too much in terms of depth, eg there's nothing on databases or the like, so if you already know the basics this won't be the coure for you.

results.content: Fairly basic course, but good explanations.  It gave me a high-level overview of OOP sites using PHP.  If you are looking for a more in-depth course, this is probably not it.  I would have liked to see more real-world examples.  The instructor uses a game as an example in the course, which did help understand a context that this type of programming would be used in, but I would have liked to see a bit more about how this would fit into a website vs a game.

results.content:
This course covers php classes in a sufficient level, for self sufficient study. It will integrate nicely with any web host.

Mr Percival gives you the deluxe tour of the class system, using real-world terms that all users will understand. You are given sufficient guidance to choose a reliable host. Any cPanel or plain PHP 5 enabled host will serve you well.

The source code for each step of the course is attached, to help avoid repeat typing and transcription errors. Avoiding errors is always best for young programmers. If you need further help, please try the discussion blog built into the uDemy course. Your fellow students are ready to assist you with the finer details of syntax and system behaviour. Mr Percival will also refine and improve his courses, based on this forum and direct feedback from his customers.

results.content: First chapters are pretty clear but non-web-related examples of PHP classes, objects, properties, and methods (including private, protected, public, and static).  However, the learning curve in the last chapter goes straight up, feels a bit rushed, inadequate introductory overview, and did not make any sense to me until the very last lecture in the last chapter.  It was not clear what gets called when, where, and why for individual pages of a site, even though I have dabbled in procedural PHP and even SSI's for headers and footers before.     This was partly because the only page actually created was Index.php.   Questions not answered until the end (and even then only implied) were:  Does the 'site' object remain in memory from first index.php page visit or recreated for each child page?   How does the user navigate between pages?  There were no lecture by lecture resources in the last chapter either (just a last chapter zip file).   Code could be commented to explain better.   Anyone with some OOP exposure in the past and persistance will likely be able to decode how to create an OOP PHP website based on the single page example.com used in the illustration, but it would have been helpful to fill things out a bit more.  I've subscribed to his Complete Web Developer course and hope that will fill in any lingering questions.

results.content: I have found this course to be a helpful introduction to php and concepts in object-oriented programming.  However, if you are looking for tangible, practical examples of these concepts this may not be the course for you.  If you are good at abstract thinking, you may be able to put the content of this course into practise, but if you are better at learning by example you'll want to use this course as a stepping stone to other php courses, or a reference to come back to.  The course itself is well-paced, the instructor is a great speaker, and the content quality is of the high standard I have come to expect from Rob.
results.content_html: I have found this course to be a helpful introduction to php and concepts in object-oriented programming. However, if you are looking for tangible, practical examples of these concepts this may not be the course for you. If you are good at abstract thinking, you may be able to put the content of this course into practise, but if you are better at learning by example you'll want to use this course as a stepping stone to other php courses, or a reference to come back to. results.content:
This course is exactly what you need to get onto the road of creating a properly useful website, i.e. a web app, and in turn have the ability to automate a large part of your business.

Taking this course has given me the necessary foundation in knowledge to move on to courses on MVC.

Most importantly the instructor makes learning to code very rewarding and hence enjoyable, due to his style of 'build along with him', which includes his making the occasional error and correction, in itself invaluable to the beginner coder.

Finally the instructor seems to really care about every one of his students, past and present. He is extremely prompt to reply to every query I've ever had. This is especially impressive given the number of courses he has on udemy and the fact that he runs a hosting company.

I couldn't be more grateful. I think that I have learned more about web development from the two courses of this instructor's that I've taken than from all the other resources I've used combined, and in much less time. I'm now well on the way to launching my business, which wouldn't have been possible without the knowledge, skills and support I have received.

I realise I sound like an evangelist.. but honestly, if you want to learn web development from scratch then the courses from this instructor are an excellent place to start!

Happy coding :-)

results.content:
Rob has hit another home run with this course. 

The basics of OOP in php are presented in small easy-to-understand steps. This makes it very easy to grasp and apply practically to your own php pages.

It is amazing how much ground is covered in so little time without overwhelming you with too much at a time.

I have been maintaining my own Wordpress website now for over a year, which is php based. While I have made numerous customization, the structure behind my theme is much clearer now after having completed this course.

I have also taken Rob's "Complete Web Developers Course". I highly recommend that one as well if you seriously seek exposure to many of the web development methods but feel overwhelmed. Once again, with this course, simple & small steps are presented that almost anyone can comprehend.

results.content:
This course is a good way to get introduced to OOP. I say introduced because it is a very good tool to help you understand how OOP is used in form. It's also good to brush up on your technical terms in case you need them for college.

This course however, is not a good way to learn how to use OOP in PHP in a practical sense. What I'm talking about is the building a site part of it.

As you can see, the building a site part of it is very short. I'd honestly call it negligible as it shows you how to make a site template, rather than how to build a site purely out of oop.

The free hosting is 'ok', it doesn't strike me as a particularly great hosting provider as it's rather fiddly. A domain name not included btw, wasn't expecting it but just an fyi for people who don't know much about hosting.

So why does this still get 3/5 stars from me despite a rather 'meh' response? Simply because Rob was a good teacher.

His pace was good, his setup doesn't make him too loud or too soft, and he goes into detail.
I also very  much liked the mid-course 'You do this now, and then we'll see how I did it.'-part.

results.content:
Rob Percival quickly walks you through the basics of OOP in this fast moving course.  I've taken multiple courses taught by Rob and as always his examples are well easy to follow and understand.  

The course builds up to a final section in which you build a basic template and create a working OOP based website.  The instructions work but I wanted a bit more explanation about some of the steps taken (the final section jumps from previously working with a single .php document to creating a site built from 6 different docs very abruptly).  

Two technical notes: in the final section you will use a Heredoc string (<<<EOT ... EOT;) and it is imperative that you have NOTHING on the line after the EOT at the beginning or before the closing EOT including spaces and tabs - Rob fixes his original error with a jumpcut which could leave you struggling to find a fix.  Second, lecture 21 never worked for me and other students echoed similar concerns in the comments - I tried the code in 3 different browsers (Firefox, Chrome, and Safari) and it stalled while trying to load in all three.

results.content:
Object oriented programming can be hard to wrap your mind around.  I've waded through a book or two on the topic and no one put the pieces together as clearly as Rob has.  Thank you Rob!

The best thing about this course is that Rob lucidly takes you from "A" to "Z" where he covers all the necessary essentials and leaves you with a working template that you can use as an OOP foundation for any PHP enhanced website you want to build.

I feel more comfortable with OOP after completing Rob's course than any book on the subject has ever managed to make me feel.

I believe I truly will be using OOP more now that I've completed this course.  The power of OOP is realized when building and maintaining large websites.   I have a couple I might be interested in revisiting so I can exercise my new found OOP muscles.  But, with the template Rob leaves you with even smaller websites can be done without the normal wondering of how do I put the OOP pieces together.  And, should the small grow into large they are set to benefit from all OOP has to offer.

This course is short and sweet.  If you've ever had a difficult time wrapping your mind around OOP concepts or just want an introduction to OOP, I think this course is great!

Thanks again Rob!  I really enjoyed it!

results.content:
I understand that this course is just meant to teach you about a small subset of PHP, but nevertheless, it is disappointing. 

Firstly, I was told that these skills would help extend the use of CMS's and eCommerce systems, but the course makes NO mention to how to do that.

All it teaches is basic OOP concepts. Sure, they are useful, but Rob really misses a great opportunity to use the concepts to make "projects" which were the main amazing feature of his Complete Web Developer course. The projects here are rushed and only the very last one is actually properly practical (it actually makes a functioning website. Rob uses video games to help explain OOP concepts, and it would be great if we made a final game using the OOP concepts to tie it together.

It is also a shame that Rob didn't touch on PDO, an object-oriented way to interface with databases. 

If you get this course to supplement the Complete Web Developer course, make sure you get it when it's on sale. Otherwise, it is not worth the learning material.
